pull.title: refactor: Remove negative lock annotations from globals
pull.body: They only make sense for mutexes that are private members. Until cs_main is a private member the negative annotations should be replaced by excluded annotations, which are optional.

events.body: Concept ACK (in the light of #20272 discussion).

Tested faadb1b050dd37ea8d294def554f1da22029d3e6 on Ubuntu 21.10:
```
$ clang --version
Ubuntu clang version 12.0.0-++rc3-4ubuntu1
Target: x86_64-pc-linux-gnu
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /usr/bin
```

With this PR massive TSA warnings are gone.

Could the global namespace be explicitly used for global mutexes in the touched lines?
This change reverts the @ajtowns's [idea](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19668#issuecomment-669312538) for `AssertLockNotHeld` but I cannot see the way to save it, unfortunately.
Approach ACK, +1 on doc change as well

refactor: Remove negative lock annotations from globals

events.message: refactor: Remove negative lock annotations from globals

events.body:
> This change reverts

Correct, but the revert is only temporary (until cs_main is removed or a private member)

ACK fa5eabe72117f6e3704858e8d5b2c57a120258ed

No warnings with Clang 13.
This pull was done in light of https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/20272#discussion_r515215137 . If https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/24931 fixes the mentioned issues, then that is fine.

Yes, it has to be propagated, but I wouldn't call it a "problem" though because it works exactly as intended. True that it creates inconvenience with code isolation (like this code should not know about that mutex), but after all a global mutex is not isolated, so IMO it is ok and even desirable to propagate its negative annotation.
